header.title: dbg

description.p:
This module implements a text-based interface to the erlang:trace/3 and
erlang:trace_pattern/2 BIFs. It makes it possible to trace functions, processes, ports, and messages.
To get started quickly on tracing function calls, you can use the following code in the Erlang shell:
For more examples on how to use dbg from the Erlang shell, see section Simple Examples - Tracing from the Shell.

The utilities are also suitable to use in system testing on large systems, where other tools have too much impact on the system performance. Some primitive support for sequential tracing is also included, see section Advanced Topics - Combining with seq_trace.

func.name: c(Mod, Fun, Args)
func.fsummary: Evaluate apply(M,F,Args) with all trace flags set.

desc.p: Same as c(Mod, Fun, Args, all).

func.name: c(Mod, Fun, Args, Flags)
func.fsummary: Evaluate apply(M,F,Args) with Flags trace flags set.

desc.p: Evaluates the expression apply(Mod, Fun, Args) with the trace flags in Flags set. This is a convenient way to trace processes from the Erlang shell.

func.name: cn(Nodename) -> ok
func.fsummary: Clear a node from the list of traced nodes.

desc.p: Clears a node from the list of traced nodes. The following calls to tp/2 and p/2 will not consider that node, but tracing already activated on the node will continue to be in effect.
Returns ok, cannot fail.

func.name: ctp({Module, Function, Arity}) -> {ok, MatchDesc} | {error, term()}
func.fsummary: Clear call trace pattern for the specified functions.

desc.p: Disables call tracing on the specified functions. The semantics of the parameter is the same as for the corresponding function specification in tp/2 or tpl/2. Both local and global call trace are disabled.
The return value reflects how many functions that matched, and is constructed as described in tp/2. A tuple {saved, N} is, however, not returned (for obvious reasons).

func.fsummary: Clear trace pattern for the specified event.

desc.p: Clears match specifications for the specified trace event (send or 'receive'). Reverts to the default behavior of tracing all triggered events.
The return value follows the same style as for ctp/1.

func.name: dtp() -> ok
func.fsummary: Delete all saved match specifications.

desc.p: Use this function to "forget" all match specifications saved during calls to tp/2. This is useful when one wants to restore other match specifications from a file with rtp/1.
To delete specific saved match specifications, use dtp/1.

func.name: fun2ms(LiteralFun) -> MatchSpec
func.fsummary: Pseudo function that transforms fun syntax to match_spec.

desc.p: Pseudo function that, by means of a parse_transform, translates the literal fun() typed as parameter in the function call to a match specification, as described in section Match Specifications in Erlang in the ERTS User's Guide. (With literal is meant that the fun() must textually be written as the parameter of the function; it cannot be held in a variable that in turn is passed to the function.)

The parse transform is provided in the ms_transform module and the source must include the ms_transform.hrl file in STDLIB for this pseudo function to work. Failing to include the hrl file in the source results in a runtime error, not a compile time error. The include file is easiest included by adding the line -include_lib("stdlib/include/ms_transform.hrl"). to the source file.

The fun() is very restricted. It can take only a single parameter (the parameter list to match), a single variable, or a list. It must use the is_XXX guard tests and one cannot use language constructs that have no representation in a match specification (such as if, case, or receive). The return value from the fun is the return value of the resulting match specification.
Example:
Variables from the environment can be imported, so that this works:
desc.pre: 2> X=3. 3 3> dbg:fun2ms(fun([M,N]) when N > X -> return_trace() end). [{['$1','$2'],[{'>','$2',{const,3}}],[{return_trace}]}]
desc.p: The imported variables will be replaced by match specification const expressions, which is consistent with the static scoping for Erlang fun()s. However, local or global function calls cannot be in the guard or body of the fun. Calls to built-in match specification functions is of course allowed:
desc.pre: 4> dbg:fun2ms(fun([M,N]) when N > X, is_atomm(M) -> return_trace() end). Error: fun containing local erlang function calls ('is_atomm' called in guard)\ cannot be translated into match_spec {error,transform_error} 5> dbg:fun2ms(fun([M,N]) when N > X, is_atom(M) -> return_trace() end). [{['$1','$2'],[{'>','$2',{const,3}},{is_atom,'$1'}],[{return_trace}]}]
desc.p: As shown in the example, the function can be called from the shell too. The fun() must be literally in the call when used from the shell as well. Other means than the parse_transform are used in the shell case, but more or less the same restrictions apply (the exception is records, as they are not handled by the shell).

warning.p: If the parse_transform is not applied to a module that calls this pseudo function, the call fails in runtime (with a badarg). The dbg module actually exports a function with this name, but it is never really to be called except when using the function in the shell. If the parse_transform is properly applied by including the ms_transform.hrl header file, the compiled code never calls the function, but the function call is replaced by a literal match specification.

desc.p: For more information, see stdlib:ms_transform.

func.name: get_tracer()
func.fsummary: Same as get_tracer(node()).

desc.p: Same as get_tracer(node()).

func.name: get_tracer(Nodename) -> {ok, Tracer}
func.fsummary: Return the process or port to which all trace messages are sent.

desc.p: Returns the process, port, or tracer module to which all trace messages are sent.

func.name: h() -> ok
func.fsummary: Get a list of available help items on standard output.

desc.p: Returns a list of items for brief online help.

func.name: h(Item) -> ok
func.fsummary: Brief help for an item.

desc.p: Returns a brief help text for functions in the dbg module. The available items can be listed with h/0.

func.name: i() -> ok
func.fsummary: Get information about all traced processes and ports.

desc.p: Returns information about all traced processes and ports.

func.name: ln() -> ok
func.fsummary: Show the list of traced nodes on the console.

desc.p: Returns the list of traced nodes on the console.

func.name: ltp() -> ok
func.fsummary: List saved and built-in match specifications on the console.

desc.p: Use this function to recall all match specifications previously used in the session (that is, previously saved during calls to tp/2, and built-in match specifications. This is very useful, as a complicated match specification can be quite awkward to write. Notice that the match specifications are lost if stop/0 is called.
Match specifications used can be saved in a file (if a read-write file system is present) for use in later debugging sessions, see wtp/1 and rtp/1.

Three built-in trace patterns exist: exception_trace, caller_trace, and caller_exception_trace (or x, c, and cx, respectively). Exception trace sets a trace which will show function names, parameters, return values, and exceptions thrown from functions. Caller traces display function names, parameters, and information about which function called it. An example using a built-in alias:
desc.pre: (x@y)4> dbg:tp(lists,sort,cx). {ok,[{matched,nonode@nohost,2},{saved,cx}]} (x@y)4> lists:sort([2,1]). (<0.32.0>) call lists:sort([2,1]) ({erl_eval,do_apply,5}) (<0.32.0>) returned from lists:sort/1 -> [1,2] [1,2]

func.name: n(Nodename) -> {ok, Nodename} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Add a remote node to the list of traced nodes.

desc.p: The dbg server keeps a list of nodes where tracing is to be performed. Whenever a tp/2 call or a p/2 call is made, it is executed for all nodes in this list, including the local node (except for p/2 with a specific pid() or port() as first argument; the command then executes only on the node where the designated process or port resides).

This function adds a remote node (Nodename) to the list of nodes where tracing is performed. It starts a tracer process on the remote node, which will send all trace messages to the tracer process on the local node (through the Erlang distribution). If no tracer process is running on the local node, error reason no_local_tracer is returned. The tracer process on the local node must be started with tracer/0,2.
If Nodename is the local node, the error reason cant_add_local_node is returned.

If a trace port (see trace_port/2) is running on the local node, remote nodes cannot be traced with a tracer process; error reason cant_trace_remote_pid_to_local_port is returned. A trace port can, however, be started on the remote node with tracer/3.
The function also returns an error if the node Nodename is unreachable.

func.name: p(Item) -> {ok, MatchDesc} | {error, term()}
func.fsummary: Trace messages to and from an item.

desc.p: Same as p(Item, [m]).

func.name: p(Item, Flags) -> {ok, MatchDesc} | {error, term()}
func.fsummary: Trace Item according to Flags.

desc.p: Traces Item according to the value specified by Flags. The variation of Item is as follows:

item.p: The corresponding process or port is traced. The process or port can be a remote process or port (on another Erlang node). The node must be in the list of traced nodes (see n/1 and tracer/3).
All processes and ports in the system as well as all processes and ports created hereafter are traced.
All processes in the system as well as all processes created hereafter are traced.
All ports in the system as well as all ports created hereafter are traced.
All processes and ports created after the call are traced.
All processes created after the call are traced.
All ports created after the call are traced.
All existing processes and ports are traced.
All existing processes are traced.
All existing ports are traced.

taglist.item: The process or port with the corresponding registered name is traced. The process or port can be a remote process (on another Erlang node). The node must be added with n/1 or tracer/3.

item.p: The process <0.Item.0> is traced.
The process <X.Y.Z> is traced.
If Item is a string "<X.Y.Z>" as returned from erlang:pid_to_list/1, the process <X.Y.Z> is traced.

desc.p: When enabling an Item that represents a group of processes, the Item is enabled on all nodes added with n/1 or tracer/3.
Flags can be a single atom or a list of flags. The available flags are as follows:

item.p: Traces the messages the process or port sends.
Traces the messages the process or port receives.
Traces the messages the process or port receives and sends.
Traces global function calls for the process according to the trace patterns set in the system (see tp/2).
Traces process-related events to the process.
Traces port-related events to the port.
Lets all processes created by the traced process inherit the trace flags of the traced process.
Lets another process, P2, inherit the trace flags of the traced process whenever the traced process links to P2.
Same as sos, but only for the first process spawned by the traced process.

Same as sol, but only for the first call to
erlang:link/1 by the traced process.
Sets all flags except silent.
Clears all flags.

desc.p:
The list can also include any of the flags allowed in
erlang:trace/3.

The function returns either an error tuple or a tuple {ok, List}. The List consists of specifications of how many processes and ports that matched (in the case of a pure pid() exactly 1). The specification of matched processes is {matched, Node, N}. If the remote processor call, rpc, to a remote node fails, the rpc error message is delivered as a fourth argument and the number of matched processes is 0. Notice that the result {ok, List} can contain a list where rpc calls to one, many, or even all nodes failed.

func.name: rtp(Name) -> ok | {error, Error}
func.fsummary: Read saved match specifications from file.

desc.p: Reads match specifications from a file (possibly) generated by wtp/1. Checks the syntax of all match specifications and verifies that they are correct. The error handling principle is "all or nothing", that is, if some of the match specifications are wrong, none of the specifications are added to the list of saved match specifications for the running system.

The match specifications in the file are merged with the current match specifications, so that no duplicates are generated. To see what numbers were assigned to the specifications from the file, use ltp/0.

The function returns an error, either because of I/O problems (like a non-existing or non-readable file) or because of file format problems. The errors from a bad format file are in a more or less textual format, which gives a hint to what is causing the problem.

func.name: stop() -> ok
func.fsummary: Stop the dbgserver and the tracing of all processes.

desc.p: Stops the dbg server and clears all trace flags for all processes and all local trace patterns for all functions. Also shuts down all trace clients and closes all trace ports.
Notice that no global trace patterns are affected by this function.

func.name: stop_clear() -> ok
func.fsummary: Stop the dbgserver and the tracing of all processes, and clear trace patterns.

desc.p: Same as stop/0, but also clears all trace patterns on global functions calls.

func.name: stop_trace_client(Pid) -> ok
func.fsummary: Stop a trace client gracefully.

desc.p: Shuts down a previously started trace client. The Pid argument is the process ID returned from the trace_client/2 or trace_client/3 call.

func.name: tp(Module,MatchSpec)
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced global function calls.

desc.p: Same as tp({Module, '_', '_'}, MatchSpec).

func.name: tp(Module,Function,MatchSpec)
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced global function calls.

desc.p: Same as tp({Module, Function, '_'}, MatchSpec).

func.name: tp(Module, Function, Arity, MatchSpec)
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced global function calls.

desc.p: Same as tp({Module, Function, Arity}, MatchSpec).

func.name: tp({Module, Function, Arity}, MatchSpec) -> {ok, MatchDesc} | {error, term()}
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced global function calls.

desc.p: Enables call trace for one or more functions. All exported functions matching argument {Module, Function, Arity} are concerned, but the match_spec() can further narrow down the set of function calls generating trace messages.

For a description of the match_spec() syntax, see section Match Specifications in Erlang in the ERTS User's Guide. The most common generic match specifications used can be found as Built-inAlias; for details, see ltp/0.

The Module, Function, and/or Arity parts of the tuple can be specified as the atom '_', which is a "wildcard" matching all modules/functions/arities. Notice that if the Module is specified as '_', the Function and Arity parts must also be specified as '_'. The same holds for the Function relation to the Arity.
All nodes added with n/1 or tracer/3 are affected by this call. If Module is not '_', the module ia loaded on all nodes.

The function returns either an error tuple or a tuple {ok, List}. The List consists of specifications of how many functions that matched, in the same way as the processes and ports are presented in the return value of p/2.

The return value can include a tuple {saved, N} if the MatchSpec is other than []. The integer N can then be used in the following calls to this function and will stand as an "alias" for the specified expression. There are also some built-in aliases for common expressions; for details, see ltp/0.

If an error is returned, the reason can be errors in compilation of the match specification. Such errors are presented as a list of tuples {error, string()}, where the string is a textual explanation of the compilation error, for example:
desc.pre: (x@y)4> dbg:tp({dbg,ltp,0},[{[],[],[{message, two, arguments}, {noexist}]}]). {error, [{error,"Special form 'message' called with wrong number of arguments in {message,two,arguments}."}, {error,"Function noexist/1 does_not_exist."}]}

func.name: tpe(Event, MatchSpec) -> {ok, MatchDesc} | {error, term()}
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced event.

desc.p: Associates a match specification with trace event send or 'receive'. By default all executed send and 'receive' events are traced if enabled for a process. A match specification can be used to filter traced events based on sender, receiver, and/or message content.
For a description of the match_spec() syntax, see section Match Specifications in Erlang in the ERTS User's Guide.

item.p: For send, the matching is done on the list [Receiver, Msg]. Receiver is the process or port identity of the receiver and Msg is the message term. The pid of the sending process can be accessed with the guard function self/0.

For 'receive', the matching is done on the list [Node, Sender, Msg]. Node is the node name of the sender. Sender is the process or port identity of the sender, or the atom undefined if the sender is unknown (which can be the case for remote senders). Msg is the message term. The pid of the receiving process can be accessed with the guard function self/0.

desc.p: All nodes added with n/1 or tracer/3 are affected by this call.
The return value is the same as for tp/2. The number of matched events is never higher than 1, as tpe/2 does not accept any form of wildcards for argument Event.

func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced local (and global) function calls.

desc.p: Same as tpl({Module, '_', '_'}, MatchSpec).

func.name: tpl(Module,Function,MatchSpec)
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced local (and global) function calls.

desc.p: Same as tpl({Module, Function, '_'}, MatchSpec).

func.name: tpl(Module, Function, Arity, MatchSpec)
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced local (and global) function calls.

desc.p: Same as tpl({Module, Function, Arity}, MatchSpec).

func.name: tpl({Module, Function, Arity}, MatchSpec) -> {ok, MatchDesc} | {error, term()}
func.fsummary: Set pattern for traced local (and global) function calls.

desc.p: Works as tp/2, but enables tracing for local calls (and local functions) as well as for global calls (and functions).

func.name: trace_client(Type, Parameters) -> pid()
func.fsummary: Start a trace client that reads messages created by a trace port driver.

desc.p: Starts a trace client that reads the output created by a trace port driver and handles it in mostly the same way as a tracer process created by tracer/0.
Allowed values for Type>:

item.p: The client reads all trace messages stored in the file named Filename or specified by WrapFilesSpec (must be the same as used when creating the trace, see trace_port/2). and lets the default handler function format the messages on the console. This is one way to interpret the data stored in a file by the file trace port driver.

The client behaves as in the file case, but keeps trying to read (and process) more data from the file until stopped by
stop_trace_client/1. WrapFilesSpec is not allowed as second argument for this Type.

The client connects to the TCP/IP port PortNumber on the host Hostname, from where it reads trace messages until the TCP/IP connection is closed. If no Hostname is specified, the local host is assumed.

desc.p: As an example, one can let trace messages be sent over the network to another Erlang node (preferably not distributed), where the formatting occurs:
On the node stack there is an Erlang node ant@stack. In the shell, type the following:
desc.pre: ant@stack> dbg:tracer(port, dbg:trace_port(ip,4711)). <0.17.0> ant@stack> dbg:p(self(), send). {ok,1}
desc.p: All trace messages are now sent to the trace port driver, which in turn listens for connections on the TCP/IP port 4711. If we want to see the messages on another node, preferably on another host, we do like this:
Assume we now send a message from the shell on the node ant@stack, where all sends from the shell are traced:
The following is diplayed at the console on the node that started the trace client:
The last line is generated because of internal message passing in the Erlang shell. The process IDs will vary.

func.name: trace_client(Type, Parameters, HandlerSpec) -> pid()
func.fsummary: Start a trace client that reads messages created by a trace port driver, with a user-defined handler.

desc.p: Works as trace_client/2, but allows you to write your own handler function. The handler function works mostly as the one described in tracer/2, but must also be prepared to handle trace messages of the form {drop, N}, where N is the number of dropped messages. This pseudo trace message occurs only if the ip trace driver is used.
For trace type file, the pseudo trace message end_of_trace is displayed at the end of the trace. The return value from the handler function is in this case ignored.

func.name: trace_port(Type, Parameters) -> fun()
func.fsummary: Create and return a trace port generating fun.

type.v: WrapFilesSpec = {Filename, wrap, Suffix} | {Filename, wrap, Suffix, WrapSize} | {Filename, wrap, Suffix, WrapSize, WrapCnt}

desc.p: Creates a trace port generating fun. The fun takes no arguments and returns a newly opened trace port. The return value from this function is suitable as a second parameter to tracer/2, that is, dbg:tracer(port, dbg:trace_port(ip, 4711)).
A trace port is an Erlang port to a dynamically linked-in driver that handles trace messages directly, without the overhead of sending them as messages in the Erlang virtual machine.

Two trace drivers are provided, the file and the ip trace drivers. The file driver sends all trace messages into one or more binary files, from where they later can be fetched and processed with trace_client/2. The ip driver opens a TCP/IP port where it listens for connections. When a client (preferably started by calling trace_client/2 on another Erlang node) connects, all trace messages are sent over the IP network for further processing by the remote client.
Using a trace port significantly lowers the overhead imposed by using tracing.

The file trace driver expects a filename or a wrap files specification as parameter. A file is written with a high degree of buffering, so all trace messages are not guaranteed to be saved in the file if a system crash occurs. That is the price to pay for low tracing overhead.

A wrap files specification is used to limit the disk space consumed by the trace. The trace is written to a limited number of files, each with a limited size. The actual filenames are Filename ++ SeqCnt ++ Suffix, where SeqCnt counts as a decimal string from 0 to WrapCnt and then around again from 0. The following applies:

item.p: When a trace term written to the current file makes it longer than WrapSize, that file is closed.
If the number of files in this wrap trace is as many as WrapCnt, the oldest file is deleted and then a new file is opened to become the current.
Thus, when a wrap trace has been stopped, at most WrapCnt trace files are saved with a size of at least WrapSize (but not much bigger), except for the last file that can even be empty.

desc.p: The default values are WrapSize = 128*1024 and WrapCnt = 8.
The SeqCnt values in the filenames are all in the range 0 through WrapCnt with a gap in the circular sequence. The gap is needed to find the end of the trace.
If the WrapSize is specified as {time, WrapTime}, the current file is closed when it has been open more than WrapTime milliseconds, regardless if the file is empty or not.

The ip trace driver has a queue of QueSize messages waiting to be delivered. If the driver cannot deliver messages as fast as they are produced by the runtime system, a special message is sent, which indicates how many messages that are dropped. That message arrives at the handler function specified in trace_client/3 as the tuple {drop, N}, where N is the number of consecutive messages dropped. For heavy tracing, drops are likely to occur, and they surely occur if no client is reading the trace messages.

func.name: trace_port_control(Operation)
func.fsummary: Same as trace_port_control(node(),Operation).

desc.p: Same as trace_port_control(node(),Operation).

func.name: trace_port_control(Nodename,Operation) -> ok | {ok, Result} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Perform a control operation on the active trace port driver on the specified node.

desc.p: Performs a control operation on the active trace port driver on the specified node (Nodename). The allowed operations and the√≠r return values depend on which trace driver is used.
Allowed values for Operation:

item.p: This function is used to flush the internal buffers held by a trace port driver. Only the file trace driver supports this operation. Returns ok.
Returns {ok, IpPort}, where IpPort is the IP port number used by the driver listen socket. Only the ip trace driver supports this operation.

func.name: tracer() -> {ok, pid()} | {error, already_started}
func.fsummary: Start a tracer server that handles trace messages.

desc.p: Starts a server on the local node that will be the recipient of all trace messages. All the following calls to p/2 result in messages sent to the newly started trace server.

A trace server started in this way simply displays the trace messages in a formatted way in the Erlang shell (that is, use io:format). For information on how the trace message handler can be customized, see tracer/2.
To start a similar tracer on a remote node, use n/1.

func.name: tracer(Type, Data) -> {ok, pid()} | {error, Error}
func.fsummary: Start a tracer server with more parameters.

desc.p: Starts a tracer server with more parameters on the local node. The first parameter, Type, indicates if trace messages are to be handled by a receiving process (process), by a tracer port (port), or by a tracer module (module). For information about tracer ports, see trace_port/2. For information about tracer modules, see erts:erl_tracer.
Allowed values for Type>:

item.p: A message handler function can be specified (HandlerSpec). The handler function, which is to be a fun taking two arguments, will be called for each trace message, with the first argument containing the message as it is and the second argument containing the return value from the last invocation of the fun. The initial value of the second parameter is specified in the InitialData part of the HandlerSpec. The HandlerFun can choose any appropriate action to take when invoked, and can save a state for the next invocation by returning it.
The second parameter is to be a fun that takes no arguments and returns a newly opened trace port when called. Such a fun is preferably generated by calling trace_port/2.
The second parameter is to be either a tuple describing the erts:erl_tracer module to be used for tracing and the state to be used for that tracer module, or a fun returning the same tuple.

desc.p: If an error is returned, either a tracer server is already running ({error,already_started}) or the HandlerFun throws an exception.
To start a similar tracer on a remote node, use tracer/3.

func.name: tracer(Nodename, Type, Data) -> {ok, Nodename} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Start a tracer server on a specified node with more parameters.

desc.p: Equivalent to tracer/2, but acts on the specified node. A tracer is started on the node (Nodename) and the node is added to the list of traced nodes.

note.p: This function is not equivalent to n/1. While n/1 starts a process tracer that redirects all trace information to a process tracer on the local node (that is, the trace control node), tracer/3 starts a tracer of any type that is independent of the tracer on the trace control node.

desc.p: For details, see tracer/2.

func.name: wtp(Name) -> ok | {error, IOError}
func.fsummary: Write all saved and built-in match specifications to a file.

desc.p: Saves all match specifications saved during the session (during calls to tp/2) and built-in match specifications in a text file with the name designated by Name. The file format is textual, so it can be edited with an ordinary text editor, and then restored with rtp/1.
Each match specification in the file ends with a full stop (.) and new (syntactically correct) match specifications can be added to the file manually.
The function returns ok, or an error tuple where the second element contains the I/O error that made the writing impossible.

section.title: Advanced Topics - Combining with seq_trace
section.p: The dbg module is primarily targeted towards tracing through the erlang:trace/3 function. It is sometimes desired to trace messages in a more delicate way, which can be done with the help of the kernel:seq_trace module.

seq_trace provides sequential tracing (known in the AXE 10 world, and sometimes called "forlopp tracing"). dbg can interpret messages generated from seq_trace and the same tracer function for both types of tracing can be used. The seq_trace messages can even be sent to a trace port for further analysis.
As a match specification can turn on sequential tracing, the combination of dbg and seq_trace can be powerful. The follwing brief example shows a session where sequential tracing is used:

This session sets the system tracer to the same process as the ordinary tracer process (that is, <0.31.0>) and sets the trace pattern for the dbg:get_tracer function to one that has the action of setting a sequential token. When the function is called by a traced process (all processes are traced in this case), the process gets "contaminated" by the token and seq_trace messages are sent both for the server request and the response. The seq_trace:set_token([]) after the call clears the seq_trace token, so no messages are sent when the answer propagates through the shell to the console port. The output would otherwise have been more noisy.

section.title: Note of Caution
section.p: When tracing function calls on a group leader process (an I/O process), there is risk of causing a deadlock. This occurs if a group leader process generates a trace message and the tracer process, by calling the trace handler function, sends an I/O request to the same group leader. The problem only occurs if the trace handler prints to the terminal using an io function, such as io:format/2.
Notice that when dbg:p(all,call) is called, I/O processes are also traced.

A deadlock occurs in the first example because when TAB is pressed to expand the function name, the group leader (which handles character input) calls mymod:module_info(). This generates a trace message which, in turn, causes the tracer process to send an I/O request to the group leader (by calling io:format/2).

In the second example, the default trace handler function is used. This handler prints to the terminal by sending I/O requests to the user process. When Erlang is started in oldshell mode, the shell process has user as its group leader and so has the tracer process in this example. As user calls functions in lists, a deadlock occurs when the first I/O request is sent.

p.em: Suggestions for how to avoid deadlock:

item.p: Do not trace the group leader of the tracer process. If tracing has been switched on for all processes, call dbg:p(TracerGLPid,clear) to stop tracing the group leader (TracerGLPid). process_info(TracerPid,group_leader) tells you which process this is (TracerPid is returned from dbg:get_tracer/0).
Do not trace the user process if using the default trace handler function.

In your own trace handler function, either call
erlang:display/1 instead of an io function, or, if user is not used as group leader, print to user instead of the default group leader. Example: io:format(user,Str,Args).
